cytopy.flow.gating.plotting¶

Classes

Plot(gating_object, default_axis)

Class for producing static FACs plots.

Functions

plot_axis_lims(x, y, xlim, ylim)

Establish axis limits

transform_axes(data, axes_vars, transforms)

Transform axes by either logicle, log, asinh, or hyperlog transformation
class cytopy.flow.gating.plotting.Plot(gating_object, default_axis)¶

Bases: object

Class for producing static FACs plots. Must be associated to a Gating object.

Parameters

  • gating_object (Gating) – Gating object to retrieve data from for plotting

  • default_axis (str) – default value to attribute to y-axis

Methods

backgate(base_population, x, y, pgeoms, …)

This function allows for plotting of multiple populations on the backdrop of some population upstream of the given populations.

compare_control(population, ctrl_id, x, y, …)

Under the assumption that control gating has been performed on the underlying object,

plot_gate(gate_name, xlim, ylim, transforms, …)

Produce a static plot of a gate

plot_population(population_name, x, y, xlim, …)

Generate a static plot of a population
backgate(base_population: str, x: str, y: str, pgeoms: list = None, poverlay: list = None, cgeoms: list = None, coverlay: list = None, cluster_root_population: str = None, meta_clusters: bool = True, xlim: tuple = None, ylim: tuple = None, transforms: dict = None, title: str = None, figsize: tuple = (8, 8)) → None¶

This function allows for plotting of multiple populations on the backdrop of some population upstream of the given populations. Each population is highlighted by either a polygon gate (for population names listed in ‘geoms’) or a scatter plot (for population names listed in ‘overlay’)

Parameters

  • base_population (str) – upstream population to form the backdrop of plot

  • x (str) – name of the x-axis variable

  • y (str) – name of the y-axis variable

  • pgeoms (list, optional) – list of populations to display as a polygon ‘gate’

  • poverlay (list, optional) – list of populations to display as a scatter plot

  • cgeoms (list, optional) – list of clusters to display as a polygon ‘gate’

  • coverlay (list, optional) – list of clusters to display as a scatter plot

  • cluster_root_population (str, optional) – root population to retrieve clusters from (only required if values given for cgeoms and/or coverlay)

  • xlim (tuple, optional) – x-axis limits

  • ylim (tuple, optional) – y-axis limit

  • transforms (dict, optional) – dictionary of transformations to be applied to axis {‘x’ or ‘y’: transform method}

  • title (str, optional) – title for plot

  • figsize (tuple, (default=(8, 8))) – tuple of figure size to pass to matplotlib call

Returns

Return type

None

compare_control(population: str, ctrl_id: list, x: str, y: str, xlim: tuple = None, ylim: tuple = None, transforms: dict = None, figsize: tuple = (8, 8))¶

Under the assumption that control gating has been performed on the underlying object, plot the target population (overlaid on its parent population) and on the same plot, show the predicted population for controls

Parameters

  • population (str) – Population of interest

  • ctrl_id (list) – One or more controls to plot for comparison (must be valid control IDs)

  • x (str) – X-axis variable

  • y (str) – Y-axis variable

  • xlim (tuple, optional) – x-axis limits

  • ylim (tuple, optional) – y-axis limits

  • transforms (dict, optional) – How to transform axis variables (defaults to logicle transform if not given)

  • figsize (tuple) – Figure size

Returns

Return type

Matplotlib.axes

plot_gate(gate_name: str, xlim: tuple = None, ylim: tuple = None, transforms: dict = None, figsize: tuple = (5, 5)) → None¶

Produce a static plot of a gate

Parameters

  • gate_name (str) – Name of gate to plot

  • xlim (tuple, optional) – custom x-axis limit (default = None)

  • ylim (tuple, optional) – custom y-axis limit (default = None)

  • transforms (dict, optional) – dictionary object, key corresponds to one of 3 possible axes (x, y or z) and value the variable to plot (If None, defaults to logicle transform for every axis)

  • figsize (tuple, (default=(5,5))) – Figure size passed to matplotlib.pyplot.subplots call

Returns

Return type

None

plot_population(population_name: str, x: str, y: str, xlim: tuple = None, ylim: tuple = None, transforms: dict = None, sample: float = None, figsize: tuple = (5, 5), ctrl_id: str = None)¶

Generate a static plot of a population

Parameters

  • population_name (str) – name of population to plot

  • x (str) – name of x-axis dimension

  • y (str) – name of y-axis dimension

  • xlim (tuple, optional) – tuple of x-axis limits

  • ylim (tuple, optional) – tuple of y-axis limits

  • transforms (dict, optional) – dictionary object, key corresponds to one of 3 possible axes (x, y or z) and value the variable to plot (If None, defaults to logicle transform for every axis)

  • sample (float, optional) – if a float value is provided, given proportion of data is sampled prior to plotting (optional)

  • figsize (tuple, (default=(5,5))) – Figure size passed to matplotlib.pyplot.subplots call

  • ctrl_id (str, optional) – If given, the equivalent population within the associated control data is plotted

Returns

Return type

None

cytopy.flow.gating.plotting.plot_axis_lims(x: str, y: str, xlim: tuple, ylim: tuple) → tuple¶

Establish axis limits

Parameters

  • x (str) – name of x axis

  • y (str) – name of y axis

  • xlim (tuple) – custom x-axis limit

  • ylim (tuple) – custom y-axis limit

Returns

x-axis limits, y-axis limits

Return type

tuple, tuple

cytopy.flow.gating.plotting.transform_axes(data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, axes_vars: dict, transforms: dict) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame¶

Transform axes by either logicle, log, asinh, or hyperlog transformation

Parameters

  • data (Pandas.DataFrame) – pandas dataframe containing data to plot

  • axes_vars (dict) – dictionary object, key corresponds to one of 3 possible axes (x, y or z) and value the variable to plot

  • transforms (dict) – dictionary object, key corresponds to one of 3 possible axes (x, y or z) and value the transform to be applied

Returns

Transformed DataFrame

Return type

Pandas.DataFrame
